column1: What is Amazon S3?
column2: Amazon S3 is object storage built to store and retrieve any amount of data from anywhere – web sites and mobile apps, corporate applications, and data from IoT sensors or devices.

column1: What types of files can be stored in S3?
column2: You can store any type of file in S3.

column1: What is the durability design of S3?
column2: S3 is designed to deliver 99.999999999% durability.

column1: For what kind of applications does S3 store data?
column2: S3 stores data for millions of applications used by market leaders in every industry.

column1: What security and compliance capabilities does S3 offer?
column2: S3 provides comprehensive security and compliance capabilities that meet even the most stringent regulatory requirements.

column1: How does S3 assist in data management?
column2: S3 gives customers flexibility in the way they manage data for cost optimization, access control, and compliance.

column1: What are the typical use cases for S3?
column2: Backup and Storage, Application Hosting, Media Hosting, Software Delivery, and Static Website.

column1: How does query-in-place functionality in S3 work?
column2: S3 provides query-in-place functionality, allowing you to run powerful analytics directly on your data at rest in S3.

column1: How supported is Amazon S3?
column2: Amazon S3 is the most supported cloud storage service available, with integration from the largest community of third-party solutions, systems integrator partners, and other AWS services.

column1: What is the range of file sizes that can be stored in S3?
column2: Files can be anywhere from 0 bytes to 5 TB.

column1: How much storage is available in S3?
column2: There is unlimited storage available.

column1: How are files organized in S3?
column2: Files are stored in buckets.

column2: Buckets are root level folders.

column1: How are subfolders within a bucket termed?
column2: Any subfolder within a bucket is known as a “folder”.

column2: S3 is a universal namespace so bucket names must be unique globally.

column1: What is the nature of S3 in terms of data storage?
column2: S3 is a persistent, highly durable data store.

column1: What differentiates persistent data stores from transient and ephemeral data stores?
column2: Persistent data stores are non-volatile storage systems that retain data when powered off, whereas transient and ephemeral data stores lose data when powered off.

column1: What rules do bucket names have to follow?
column2: Names must be unique across all of AWS, be 3 to 63 characters in length, can only contain lowercase letters, numbers, and hyphens, and cannot be formatted as an IP address.

column1: What are the components of an object in S3?

column1: What is 'Object sharing' in S3?

column1: What is 'Lifecycle management' in S3?
column2: Lifecycle management allows setting rules to transfer objects between storage classes at defined time intervals.

column1: How can data be secured in S3?
column2: Data is secured using ACLs and bucket policies.

column2: Storage, Requests, Storage management pricing, Data transfer pricing, and Transfer acceleration.

column1: How should you select a region when creating a bucket in S3?
column2: It is a best practice to create buckets in regions that are physically closest to your users to reduce latency.

column2: With AWS Snowball (Snowball), you can transfer hundreds of terabytes or petabytes of data between your on-premises data centers and Amazon S3.

column1: What are the different AWS Snow offerings?

column1: What is Amazon Elastic Block Store (EBS)?
column2: Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) provides persistent block storage volumes for use with Amazon EC2 instances in the AWS Cloud.

column1: How does Amazon EBS ensure data availability and durability?
column2: Each Amazon EBS volume is automatically replicated within its Availability Zone to protect from component failure, offering high availability and durability.

column1: What are the types of EBS volumes that appear on the AWS exams?
column2: EBS Provisioned IOPS SSD (io1/io2), EBS General Purpose SSD (gp2/gp3), Throughput Optimized HDD (st1), and Cold HDD (sc1).

column1: Does EBS volume data persist independently of the life of the instance?
column2: Yes, EBS volume data persists independently of the life of the instance.

column1: Do EBS volumes need to be attached to an instance?
column2: No, EBS volumes do not need to be attached to an instance.

column1: Can you attach multiple EBS volumes to an instance?
column2: Yes, you can attach multiple EBS volumes to an instance.

column1: Can you attach an EBS volume to multiple instances?
column2: No, you cannot attach an EBS volume to multiple instances (use Elastic File Store instead).

column1: Do EBS volumes need to be in the same AZ as the instances they are attached to?
column2: Yes, EBS volumes must be in the same AZ as the instances they are attached to.

column1: Are root EBS volumes deleted on termination by default?
column2: Yes, Root EBS volumes are deleted on termination by default.

column1: Are extra non-boot volumes deleted on termination by default?
column2: No, Extra non-boot volumes are not deleted on termination by default.

column1: What are EBS Snapshots?
column2: Snapshots capture a point-in-time state of an instance and are stored on S3.

column1: What are Instance store volumes?
column2: Instance store volumes are high performance local disks that are physically attached to the host computer on which an EC2 instance runs.

column1: What does ephemeral mean in the context of instance stores?
column2: Ephemeral means the data is lost when powered off (non-persistent).

column1: For what purpose are instance stores ideal?
column2: Instance stores are ideal for temporary storage of information that changes frequently, such as buffers, caches, or scratch data.

column1: Where are Instance store volume root devices created from?
column2: Instance store volume root devices are created from AMI templates stored on S3.

column1: Can Instance store volumes be detached/reattached?
column2: No, Instance store volumes cannot be detached/reattached.

column2: EFS is a fully managed service that makes it easy to set up and scale file storage in the Amazon Cloud.

column1: Up to what size can EFS scale?

column1: What does the AWS shared responsibility model define?
column2: The AWS shared responsibility model defines what the AWS account holder/user and AWS are responsible for in terms of security and compliance.

column1: What is the shared responsibility between AWS and the customer?
column2: Security and Compliance is a shared responsibility between AWS and the customer.

column1: How does the shared model help customers?
column2: This shared model can help relieve customer’s operational burdens as AWS operates, manages, and controls components from the host operating system and virtualization layer down to the physical security of the facilities.

column1: What is the customer's responsibility in the AWS shared responsibility model?
column2: The customer assumes responsibility and management of the guest operating system (including updates and security patches), other associated application software, and the configuration of the AWS provided security group firewall.

column1: What does 'Security of the Cloud' refer to and who is responsible for it?
column2: 'Security of the Cloud' refers to AWS's responsibility for protecting the infrastructure that runs all the services offered in the AWS Cloud. AWS is responsible for this.

column1: What composes the infrastructure of the AWS Cloud?
column2: This infrastructure is composed of the hardware, software, networking, and facilities that run AWS Cloud services.

column1: Who is responsible for 'Security in the Cloud'?
column2: Customers are responsible for 'Security in the Cloud'.

column1: What are some responsibilities of customers for EC2 in terms of security?
column2: For EC2, customers are responsible for network level security (NACLs, security groups), operating system patches and updates, IAM user access management, and client and server-side data encryption.

column1: What are 'Inherited Controls' in the AWS shared responsibility model?
column2: 'Inherited Controls' are controls which a customer fully inherits from AWS, such as Physical and Environmental controls.

column1: What are 'Shared Controls'?
column2: 'Shared Controls' are controls that apply to both the infrastructure layer and customer layers, but in separate contexts or perspectives.

column1: In the AWS shared security model, how does a shared control function?
column2: In the shared security model, AWS provides the requirements for the infrastructure and the customer must provide their own control implementation within their use of AWS services.

column1: Give examples of shared controls in the AWS shared responsibility model.
column2: Examples of shared controls include Patch Management, Configuration Management, and Awareness & Training.

column1: How does Patch Management work as a shared control?
column2: AWS is responsible for patching and fixing flaws within the infrastructure, while customers are responsible for patching their guest OS and applications.

column1: How does Configuration Management work as a shared control?
column2: AWS maintains the configuration of its infrastructure devices, but a customer is responsible for configuring their own guest operating systems, databases, and applications.

column1: What is the difference in training between AWS and customers in the shared responsibility model?
column2: Awareness & Training indicates that AWS trains AWS employees, but a customer must train their own employees.

column1: What are 'Customer Specific' controls in the AWS shared responsibility model?
column2: 'Customer Specific' controls are solely the responsibility of the customer based on the application they are deploying within AWS services.

column1: Give examples of customer specific controls in the AWS shared responsibility model.
column2: Examples of customer specific controls include Service and Communications Protection or Zone Security which may require a customer to route or zone data within specific security environments.
